awd_abstract_narration:
A highly skilled technician workforce with expertise in anti-counterfeit processes and measures will ensure that products distributed locally and globally are more secure, reduce the risk associated with counterfeit products, and maintain the competitiveness of manufacturers. This project at Central Piedmont Community College (CPCC) is designed to meet the increasing need for product and packaging security by developing a new certificate embedded in an associate degree program focused on Functional Printing with an emphasis on the emerging role of anti-counterfeit printing and packaging technology. CPCC is one of the three colleges in North Carolina that offers an Associate of Applied Science degree in Graphic Arts and Imaging Technology, and the only institution in the Charlotte region, which serves as an operations base for over 200 printing, manufacturing and distribution enterprises that employ 12,000 individuals. The project will  support the needs of both regional and national employers, as the project will share results from the project that can inform how companies implement security processes and measures that address brand protection and the integrity of their products. Implementation of the project will result in a talent-rich pipeline of technicians who will implement security and protection changes within manufacturing and distribution facilities, know how to modify security features demanded by manufacturers, and understand the baseline processes for anti-counterfeit printing.

By researching the evolving and emerging field of functional printing, CPCC faculty will establish a multidisciplinary certificate program in anti-counterfeit printing and packaging technology to address the need for technicians who understand security printing and brand protection measures. By engaging university-based research entities and other external partners, the college will design a transformational curriculum that is unique to two-year colleges. Through the project activities of research, curriculum development and faculty professional development, the educators involved in this project will gain additional expertise and be able to introduce technology innovations and trends to inform the development of the program. Recognizing the potential for a broad range of career pathways, the project team will bring greater understanding to this emerging technology through articulation agreements with area universities. The project will also be guided by an Advisory Committee comprised of local, regional, and national members who will ensure that the technical education meets the needs of employers and industry. Project activities will include course development and adaptation leading to a new technician certificate program offered at the two-year college as well as continuing education for incumbent workers, faculty professional development, and cultivation of business and industry partnerships. A formative and summative evaluation process will be employed to continuously enhance the project activities and provide opportunities for researching and evaluating the success of the project and deliverables, as well as the sharing of best practices. Results will be disseminated with the NSF community, as well as employer and business partners, and research entities focused on anti-counterfeiting processes and technologies. In addition, partnerships with entities focused on similar themes will promote continued collaboration and expansion of the body of knowledge to better serve business and industry as well as educational institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The International Chamber of Commerce indicates counterfeiting is one of the fastest growing economic crimes of modern times. Counterfeiting activity costs an estimated $600 billion a year. This activity compromises the reputation of legitimate businesses of all sizes, and at its most sophisticated, has the capacity to threaten national economies, and even endanger safety and lives. The broad array of commercial goods subject to infringement has increased significantly ranging from pharmaceuticals to alcoholic beverages, to furniture and wall coverings.

Given the technology available today, it is common to come across convincing forgeries of products that look genuine.  While this can be particularly detrimental for businesses, these forgeries can be extremely harmful to consumers that purchase products that have not been manufactured, handled and packaged with US regulated production and health standards (such as those mandated by the US Food and Drug Administration).

Central Piedmont Community College's (CP) Graphic Arts and  Imaging Technology program proposed to address the local need for anti-counterfeiting technicians through the development of a new certificate program in Anti-Counterfeit Printing & Packaging Technology.  CP was awarded a National Science Foundation Advanced Technological Education grant to support a project focused on Functional Printing with an emphasis on the emerging role of anti-counterfeit printing and packaging technology.  Project activities included  course development and adaptation leading to a new technician cerificate program offered at the two-year college as well as a continuing education course for incumbent workers, faculty professional development, and cultivation of business and industry partnerships. 

The project activities supported the achievement of an overarching goal to build the competitiveness of the Charlotte, NC region by educating technicians for high paying occupations in the field of anti-counterfeit printing and packaging.  This goal was accomplished through 4 primary objectives and deliverables:

Objective 1:  Research and Curriculum Development

Deliverable:  New certificate program focused on anti-counterfeiting processes and measures.

Objective 2:  Faculty Professional Development

Deliverable:  Faculty will acquire expertise on anti-counterfeit printing technology that will directly impact the design and delivery of new curriculum.

Objective 3:  Engagement of Industry Representatives and Employers

Deliverable: On-going collaboration and support from industry and employer partners.

Objective 4:  Course offering - Pilot the New Technical Education Program

Deliverable:  Technician workforce skilled in anti-counterfeit printing and packaging technology.

The certifcate curriculum included two existing foundational courses that were adapted to incorporate security components, and three newly developed courses that are specific to security and anti-counterfeiting technology.  NSF funds were used to develop the new, advanced functional printing courses that integrate the applicable anti-counterfeit printing and packaging concepts, security procedures and advanced processes that graduates will encounter in the workplace.  Research conducted by the project team, as well as input from the Graphic Arts and Imaging Technology advisory committee suggested that a fifteen credit hour, curriculum certificate comprised of  5 courses would best prepare students for advanced technician roles in anti-counterfeit printing and packaging technology in the  region. 

Anti-Counterfeit Printing & Packaging Technology Certificate

Graphic Arts I (4 credits)

Flexography (4 credits)

Introduction to Brand Protection & Anti-Counterfeiting (2 Credits) NEW

Design for Brand Protection and Anti-Coutnerfeiting (2 credits) NEW

Brand Protection and Anti-Counterfeiting Applications (3 credits) NEW

In addition, faculty development was a critical component of CP's project enabling the college to build  capacity to meet the emerging workforce needs of employers in the region.

Additional field research was conducted by traveling to entities focused on anti-counterfeiting such as the Center for Anti-Counterfeiting and Product Protection (A-CAPP) housed at Michigan State University.  A multi-disciplinary entity, A-CAPP focuses on the complex global issues of anti-counterfeiting and product protection of all products, across industries, in all markets on strategies to work effectively to detect, deter and respond to crime.

Local industry experts were engaged to inform the content of the new certificate program and review alignment with local workforce needs.  Employer partners served on an advisory committee as well as considered graduates of the program for available positions, promoted work-based learning opportunities for students such as internships, co-ops and site visits.  Employer partners committed to assist with the development of program content, review and validate curriculum, identify appropriate third-party credentials and provide information regarding industry employment needs.  Industry partners on the Advisory Committee changed their thinking about how they can interact with community colleges to embrace new technologies and training through the community colleges' workforce development function.

The new certificate program is designed as an advanced, yet integrated, complement to the Graphic Arts and Imaging Technology Associate in Applied Science degree.  While the certificate can be completed in one semester, it is anticipated that students will complete the 2 foundational courses during their first academic year, and the remaining courses in the second year.  This will enable faculty to recruit talented and interested students directly from the Graphic Arts and Imaging Technology AAS program.
